contextId.information: "to look at" is an idiom that means "to treat" or "to deal with." AT: "regarded me kindly" or "had pity on me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
"with you" is an idiom that implies support and acceptance. AT: "The Lord is pleased with you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
The idiom "among women" means "more than any other woman" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This idiom means "I heard" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
These two phrases are word pictures that together emphasize that Zechariah was suddenly able to speak. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: his mouth was opened ... his tongue was freed

contextId.information: This idiom means "go ahead of the Lord" or "come before the Lord" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: go before the face of the Lord

contextId.information: The shadow often represents something that is about to happen. Here, it refers to approaching death. AT: "who are about to die" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

"open the womb" is an idiom that refers to the first baby coming out of the womb. This referred to both animals and people. AT: "Every firstborn offspring who is a male" or "Every firstborn son" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: Every male who opens the womb

contextId.information: "God spoke his word" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This expression here means "thinking about them silently" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This belligerent response is an idiom that means: "What do we have in common?" or "What right do you have to bother us?" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: What do we have to do with you

contextId.information: This is an idiom that means "was very sick with" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
To "follow" someone was a term that means to become their disciple. AT: "Be my disciple" or "Come, follow me as your teacher" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This idiom means "be extremely joyful" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

The idiom "in the hearing" emphasizes that he wanted them to hear what he said. AT: "to the people who were listening to him" or "to the people who were present" or "for the people to hear" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: in the hearing of the people

contextId.information: This phrase is an idiom that means "come into my house." If your language has an idiom that means "come into my house," think about whether it would be good to use here. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

Possible meanings are 1) "Everyone" since everyone has ears or 2) "Whoever has the ability to understand" which refers to those who are willing to listen to God. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This idiom means "they stop believing" or "they stop following Jesus" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This idiom means "Why are you bothering me?" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: What have you to do with me

contextId.information: "sitting at the feet" is an idiom that means "sitting humbly nearby" or "sitting in front of." AT: "sitting on the ground in front of Jesus" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: sitting at the feet of Jesus

contextId.information: This idiom means they ate enough food so they were not hungry. AT: "they had as much as they wanted to eat" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This idiom means "die" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This is an idiom that means they should pay attention. AT: "Listen carefully and remember" or "Do not forget this" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: Let these words go deeply into your ears

contextId.information: This idiom means he "firmly decided." AT: "made up his mind" or "decided" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

Moving around from house to house means going to different houses. It can be made clear that he was talking about staying overnight at different houses. "Do not go sleep at a different house each night" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]] and  [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: Do not move around from house to house

contextId.information: This idiom means "almost dead." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This idiom means that she came from very far away. AT: "she came a very great distance" or "she came from a place very far away" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: she came from the ends of the earth

contextId.information: This is an idiom that means, "descendant of Abraham" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

Possible meanings are 1) "Everyone" since everyone has ears or 2) "Whoever has the ability to understand" which refers to those who are willing to listen to God. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: He who has ears to hear

contextId.information: This idiom means "came to his senses." AT: "clearly understood his situation" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This idiom means "he looked up" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This idiom means to speak loudly. AT: "they called with a loud voice" or "they called aloud" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
To "lift up his eyes" means to look at something. AT: "look toward heaven" or "look upward" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: lift up his eyes to heaven

contextId.information: "about the distance that someone can throw a stone." AT: "a short distance" or with an estimated measurement like "about thirty meters" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

"I do not know what you are talking about." This expression means that Peter completely disagree with the man. AT: "what you said is not true at all" or "what you said is completely false" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: I do not know what you are saying

contextId.information: This is an idiom that means the statement is correct. AT: "What you said is correct" or "It is just as you have asked me" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This is an idiom that means "began to act." Whether Peter was sitting or standing when he decided to act is not important. AT: "started out" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
To "open the mind" is an idiom that means to enable someone to understand. AT: "Then he enabled them to understand the scriptures" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: Then he opened their minds, that they might understand the scriptures
